records.line: Everything is water in one form or another.

records.line: The earth is a cylindrical solid object hanging in space, equidistant to everything else.

records.line: We remember a lot of what we know from a previous life.

records.line: Mathematical order pervades the physical world.

records.line: We may get nearer and nearer to the truth but our knowledge is our creation; it is in fact conjecture.

records.line: Each group shapes their gods in the likeness of their own.

records.line: Everything is a coming together of opposites.

records.line: There are no stable ‘things’; everything is flux, changing all the time.

records.line: A hidden connection is stronger than an obvious one.

records.line: It is not possible to step into the same river twice.

records.line: There can never have been nothing; everything must always have existed.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: It is not possible for anything to pass into nothing; everything is eternal.

records.line: The universe is a single unchanging entity; all is one.

records.line: What appears as change is something that occurs within an enclosed and unchanging system.

records.line: Everything is made up of indivisible particles (atoms) that are too small to be seen.

records.line: All change in the universe consists of atoms altering formations or locations.

records.line: The universe is not a continuum, but consists of separate entities.

records.line: An impeccably logical argument can lead to a false conclusion.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Knowledge of the universe does not affect our behaviour.

records.line: We need to know how to conduct our lives and ourselves.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Things like ‘justice’ do exist; not materially, but in some sort of essence.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: To a man who preserves his integrity no real, long-term harm can ever come.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: We should pity the perpetrator of injustice, not the victim of injustice.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: No one really knowingly does wrong.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: There can be no cut and dried answers; answers themselves are open to question.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Everything is an ephemeral copy of a permanent Idea (or Form) outside space and time.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Underlying our messy world, there is another reality with all the perfection of mathematics.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The underlying perfect reality is accessible to the mind and the intellect.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: We are born possessing all knowledge; when an Idea is learned it is actually just recalled.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: In our visible world with space and time, everything is becoming, nothing is.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Our bodies are ephemeral; our souls are our permanent Forms, timeless and indestructible.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Our aim in life should be to penetrate to the level of underlying reality.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The moral Forms set the objective moral standards by which human conduct and character should be judged.
records.reference: Seven Theories of Human Nature, Leslie Stevenson, Oxford University Press, 1974

records.line: Man is made up of three conflicting elements: passion (desire, appetite), intellect (reason), and will (spirit).
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Intellect should govern passions through the will.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Virtue is not solely a matter of knowing what is right.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The only harm that can come to a person is harm to the soul.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: It is better to suffer wrong than to commit it.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Everything and everybody should be questioned, taking nothing for granted.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: A philosophically aware class should govern society through an intermediate police class for the happiness of the whole community.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Women share by nature in every way of life just as men do, but in all of them women are weaker than men.
records.reference: Republic, Plato

records.line: Girls should be brought up on equal terms with boys.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Art is doubly deceptive, creating illusory semblances of illusory semblances.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: There is only one world that we can philosophize about – the one we live in.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: If we stray beyond the ground covered by experience we wander into empty talk.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: A thing is whatever it is by virtue of its form.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The material cause of a thing is what it is made of.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The efficient cause of a thing is what does or makes it.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The formal cause of a thing is the shape by which it’s identified.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The final cause of a thing is the ultimate reason for it.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: An object’s form, though not material, is inherent in this world.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The real point of everything is what it does, what it is for.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Change occurs when the ongoing material that is part of something acquires a new form.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: What we want is a happy life.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: To be happy, we must be compatible with living in a society; personal isolation is no good.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: A virtue is the midway point between two extremes; our aim should be balance.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The purpose of government is to enable its citizens to live the happy life.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Poetry is more philosophical and more worthy of attention than history.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: When we watch a tragedy, we experience catharsis – cleansing by pity and terror.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: All men by nature desire to know.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The male is by nature superior and the female inferior, the male ruler and the female subject.
records.reference: Politics, Aristotle

records.line: Spoken words are the symbols of mental experience and written words are the symbols of spoken words.
records.reference: On Interpretation, Aristotle

records.line: All men have not the same writings or speech sounds, but the mental experiences which these directly symbolize are the same for all.
records.reference: On Interpretation, Aristotle

records.line: The only thing that matters is the difference between true values and false values.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: All social conventions (public/private, naked/clothed, etc.) are nonsense.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: I am a citizen of the world.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: People over the world believe in opposite things; knowledge is subjective.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: We cannot assume the truth of one explanation rather than any other.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: We should just go with the flow – the customs of wherever and whenever we happen to live.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: All there is in the universe are atoms and space.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Atoms are indestructible and eternal, but their combinations (objects) are always changing.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: We, body and mind, are among the ephemeral objects built of atoms.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Don’t fear death; so long as you exist, death is not, and when death is, you are not.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Gods are far away and have no desire to be involved with us; it’s as if they don’t exist.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Happiness in this world should be our aim.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The way to be happy is to withdraw from public life into private communities of like-minded people.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: We should enjoy pleasures in moderation, though no non-injurious activity needs to be forbidden.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The greatest pleasure is attainable through knowledge, friendship, and with freedom from fear.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: There can be no authority higher than reason.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The world as our reason presents it to us (the world of Nature) is all there is.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Nature is governed by rationally intelligible principles.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The rationality within us and the Nature is what is meant by God.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: God is not separate from the world – he is the mind, the self-awareness of the world.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: When we die we dissolve back into Nature; there is nowhere else to go.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: If our emotions rebel against our acceptance of mortality, they are in the wrong.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Emotions are cognitive judgements – forms of knowledge, true or false.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: With reason we can eliminate our ‘false’ emotions; we can then be one with the world.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Every proof has premises which it does not itself establish; no ultimate ground of certainty exists.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: What exists is ultimately mental; for something to be created is for it to be thought.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: There are three ascending levels of being: soul (humans), intellect, and good.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: We should be in an attempted ascent towards one-ness with the good.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The flow of time does not exist independently of experience.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The present is the inescapable mode of all existence.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Our whole worldly being, including our intellect, is dominated by our will.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: To doubt anything, I must exist; I cannot doubt that I exist – I know that with absolute certainty.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: There may be other things than our existence that we can know with absolute certainty.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Our soul is non-material and timeless, while our bodies are decaying material objects.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: True knowledge is of a realm of timeless and perfect non-material entities.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Our senses can be illusory.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: God did not create evil, because evil is not a thing, but a lack or deficiency of something.

records.line: To create rational beings, God left open the possibility that they would choose evil rather than good.
records.reference: The Philosophy Book, DK Pub., 2011

records.line: We cannot be saved through our own will alone; souls who go to hell are damned by God’s choice.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Reason and revelation are both valid ways of arriving at the same truth.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Since God is unknowable, it is impossible for Him to know himself.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Existence is greater than absence; so the most perfect being possible (God) must exist, by definition.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Reason and faith are very distinct; we believe in answers that are undecidable by reason.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: All our rational knowledge is acquired through sensory experience.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: A baby’s mind is like a clean slate (‘tabula rasa’) with nothing written on it.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: God’s own essence cannot have preceded his existence; God must be pure existence.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The soul is known by its acts.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: There is such a thing as necessity in logic but not in the natural order of things.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: We cannot learn about the world purely through logical argument; we must first observe.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The more complicated explanation is more likely to have something wrong with it.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: We should always assume the minimum we need to assume in an explanation; entities should not be posited unnecessarily.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The scientific method consists of data collection, hypothesis generation, experiment confirmation, and prediction.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Negative instances are as important as positive ones in guiding us to the right conclusions.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Our senses, feelings, and ideologies can be obstacles in our search for reliable knowledge.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Words are but the images of matter, to fall in love with them is to fall in love with a picture.

records.line: The universe consists of matter in motion, and nothing else exists; it is a vast machine.

records.line: Every moving object, including human beings, is some sort of machine.

records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Appetites (liking, love, etc.) are inherently unsatisfiable; they cannot cease until death.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The strongest aversion is the fear of death.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: At the bottom, the fear of death causes people to form societies.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: In the state of nature there is no order or justice, violence and cunning rules; life is solitary, poor, nasty, brutish and short.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Everyone should hand over power to a central authority with absolute power who imposes law.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Any tyranny is better than social chaos.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: In mathematics we start from indubitable premises and deduce irrefutable conclusions.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: To gain reliable knowledge, we should start from indubitable premises as in mathematics.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Sensual observations cannot be trusted, as they deceive us frequently.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: I cannot be absolutely sure at any moment that I am not being deceived by an evil demon controlling my senses.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The only thing I can be sure of is that I am having the experiences that I am having.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: I may not know my own nature or the nature of things, but that I exist is indubitable.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: I can think of a perfect being even though I am imperfect; therefore it (God) exists.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: If I think carefully, I can be certain of my conclusions, because God will not deceive me.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: There are two kinds of substance; mind (which I am as a conscious being) and matter.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: To understand the world we should apply the methods of mathematics to reality.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: If God is infinite, he cannot have boundaries; everything is part of God, all is one.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Religious and scientific conceptions are two ways of describing the same reality.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Dualism is false; mind and matter are one and the same thing expressed in two ways.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: All things are alive and have minds, in different degrees.
records.reference: Ethics, Benedict Spinoza, 1677

records.line: Free will is an illusion; we are mostly not aware of the causes of our actions.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Understanding that we are not free can liberate us, coming to terms with things as they are.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Our personal problems are insignificant in the totality of things.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Freedom of speech is necessary to secure the public order.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The true aim of government is liberty.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: We should analyze our mental faculties and find out their limits; we cannot know everything.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: What we have direct experience of are the contents of our own consciousness.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The data from which we start to think should come through our senses, from the outside reality.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: When we are born the mind is like a blank slate on which experience begins to write.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Science can deal with primary (objective, measurable) qualities; length, weight, velocity, etc.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Secondary (subjective) qualities are out of the reach of science: taste, smell, colour, etc.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: We can only know the properties of a thing, not the material thing in itself.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: I can only know the contents of my awareness, not the thing (self) that is having those experiences.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Possible knowledge consists entirely of transactions between the mysterious subject and object.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Because knowledge/science starts from observation, there is always room for error.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: We must always be willing to change our beliefs in the light of changing evidence.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: It is mistaken and morally wrong for political and religious authorities to impose beliefs.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: As made by God in His own image, mankind was not a jungle beast in the state of nature.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The social contract is made between free men because the presence of government is better.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Sovereignty ultimately remains with the people; they retain their individual rights and freedom.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: If the government abuses people’s rights, they have the moral right to overthrow it.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: If I work to produce something, then I have a right to the fruits of my labour.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: I can dispose of my property right as I wish; give it, sell it, etc., independently of government.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: There are three ‘species’: God, the source of all being; Christ, the ‘middle nature’; and ‘Creature’.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/conway/, Author: Sarah Hutton

records.line: A principle of likeness links God and creation; since God is good and just, his creation too is good and just.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/conway/, Author: Sarah Hutton

records.line: Created substance, like God, consists of spirit, but, unlike God, is constituted of particles (‘monads’).
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/conway/, Author: Sarah Hutton

records.line: All created substance is living, capable of motion and perception; inert corporeal substance would contradict the nature of God, who is life itself.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/conway/, Author: Sarah Hutton

records.line: Created substance is differentiated from the divine, principally on account of its mutability and multiplicity.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/conway/, Author: Sarah Hutton

records.line: ‘Middle nature’ (Christ) is an intermediary being (a bridge and a buffer) through which God communicates life, action, goodness and justice.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/conway/, Author: Sarah Hutton

records.line: All things are capable of becoming more spirit-like – more refined qua spiritual substance.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/conway/, Author: Sarah Hutton

records.line: All things are capable of increased goodness.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/conway/, Author: Sarah Hutton

records.line: Evil is a falling away from the perfection of God, and suffering is part of a longer term process of spiritual recovery.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/conway/, Author: Sarah Hutton

records.line: There are two kinds of truths: (analytic) truths of reasoning and (synthetic) truths of fact.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The sufficient reason for a truth of reasoning is to be found by reasoning, without reference to external reality.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The sufficient reason for a truth of fact is to be found by looking at external facts.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: There is a huge number of possible worlds.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: God, as a perfect being, created the best possible world.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: A world with free will is better than one without it; that’s why God created this world with evil.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: If you could step inside a conscious machine, you would find only mechanical parts, and never anything by which to explain consciousness.
records.reference: The Monadology, Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz, 1714

records.line: Everything, matter or mind, is made up of centers of activity (monads).
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Monads are like dots of consciousness in space; each has its own point of view and they do not intersect with each other.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Human minds are monads.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: God is a monad.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Nature makes no leaps. (The law of continuity)
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: All we can ever apprehend are the contents of our own consciousness.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: We know that we exist because we have direct awareness of being a subject of experiences.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: We can never be sure that our experiences are attached to objects external to us.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: A consistent empiricism leads us to the conclusion that what exists are only minds and their contents.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Total reality exists in God’s mind; things exist either in our minds or in God’s mind.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Besides his five external senses, man has internal senses including a sense of beauty, of morality, of honour, and of the ridiculous.
records.reference: An Inquiry into the Original of our Ideas of Beauty and Virtue, Francis Hutcheson, 1725

records.line: Moral sense is our most important sense.
records.reference: An Inquiry into the Original of our Ideas of Beauty and Virtue, Francis Hutcheson, 1725

records.line: Moral sense is implanted in man, instinctively approving virtuous actions and disapproving the vicious ones.
records.reference: Encyclopaedia Britannica, britannica.com/biography/Francis-Hutcheson

records.line: In addition to the uncultivated “state of nature”, there is the cultivated state in which we are following our benevolent nature designed by God.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/hutcheso/, Authors: Phyllis Vandenberg and Abigail DeHart

records.line: Wisdom denotes the pursuing of the best ends by the best means.
records.reference: Encyclopaedia Britannica, britannica.com/biography/Francis-Hutcheson

records.line: The action which procures the greatest happiness for the greatest numbers is the best.
records.reference: Encyclopaedia Britannica, britannica.com/biography/Francis-Hutcheson

records.line: It is only from experience that our knowledge of anything outside ourselves can come.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Introspection reveals just a bundle of sensations; the self, the experiencing subject is a fiction.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The existence of God is a question of fact and can be settled only by observation.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: There is no observational evidence for the existence of God; only some inferential, indirect arguments.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The Argument from Design is a far cry from proof of a personal God, Christian or Jew.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Causal connection cannot be observed; correlation is not causation.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: However many Xs I observe having the property y, that is no proof that the next X I see will be y.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: We should not define a cause-effect relationship as a matter of conceptual necessity.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Theoretically we cannot know anything for sure; practically we have to live as if we do know.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: We are usually not driven by reason; reason is the slave of the passions.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Only analytic statements can be known with certainty to be true.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: With this level of uncertainty, Theories of Everything (in philosophy, science, etc.) are ridiculous.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: We should hold our opinions diffidently, knowing them to be fallible, respecting those of others.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Deductions of ‘ought’ statements from ‘is’ statements need careful observation and explanation.
records.reference: A Treatise of Human Nature, David Hume, 1739

records.line: Our moral judgements express our internal, sentimental motivations; they are not derived from reason.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Beauty in things exists in the mind which contemplates them.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Man in a state of nature is a noble savage; human beings are born good, loving justice and order.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Civilization corrupts men, by repressing feelings and imposing artificial modes of thinking.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: We cannot be uncivilized, so we should change the civilization to make instincts and feelings free.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Education should not discipline a child’s natural tendencies; it should encourage them.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The tools of education should not be books but practice: experience of people and things.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Education should take place in family, not school; and through love, not rules and punishment.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Religion is a matter of the heart, not the head; emotion should dominate instead of reason.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Human society is a collective being with a will of its own.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Laws should be made by everybody deliberating and voting, expressing the ‘general will’.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The ‘general will’ might not be good for any individual, but the citizen is subordinate to it.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The rulers can give the task of execution to whoever they choose; a monarch, politicians, etc.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: A population at large might constitute an ill-informed, short-sighted legislative body.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: ‘Legislators’, charismatic leaders who understand the general will, can draft legislation and persuade people.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Society is so big and complex that a single mind cannot possibly contain and understand it.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Society is like an organism living on its own, not a machine which can be built and modified at will.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The only realistic mode of political change is organic, not revolutionary.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Each generation inherits a treasure from the past which it is its duty to pass on.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Humans are imperfect creatures, therefore the idea of a perfect society is fantasy.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Governments have to deal with people as they are, extremely unequal in talent and ambition.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The public prospers more under practical-minded men than under clever theoreticians.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Great art seeks the infinite, which cannot be clear; it has the emotional pull of the unknown, the sublime.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: What we can know is limited by our sensory organs and brains; these are tools with limitations.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The contents of consciousness, produced by our bodily apparatus, are just limited representations.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Our senses give us accurate information, but they do so as gauges, not pictures.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The mode of existence of things (noumena) has nothing to do with our impressions (phenomena) of them.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: We have no means of access to the realm of things as they are (noumena).
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: It is impossible for any being to understand its own nature.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Space, time, and causality are forms of our sensibility and understanding, not original characteristics of things.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: There are synthetic a priori judgements that are based on pure intuitions or our a priori formal representations of space and time.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/kant-judgment/, Author: Robert Hanna

records.line: Existence is not a property; it is a metaphysically necessary condition for the instantiation of any properties.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/ont-arg/, Author: Kenneth E. Himma

records.line: We cannot know/prove the existence of God/souls because it is out of the limits of our senses.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Science is the key to understand the world of material objects in space and time.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: If we are objects moving in space and time with scientific laws, we cannot have free will.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: We have moral concepts (good, right, duty, etc.), so we believe that we have free will, at least sometimes.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: We believe that there is a non-empirical realm in which decisions are made, that affects our bodies.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Morality is possible only for rational creatures capable of understanding reasons for action.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Because morality concerns the choice of action, moral judgements take the form of imperatives.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Moral world is governed by universal moral laws, just like the empirical world is by scientific laws.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: You should act only according to maxims which you can will also to be universal laws.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The rightness/wrongness of an action is determined by its consequences.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Good consequences of actions are those that give pleasure to someone (and bad – pain).
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: A right course of action is the one that maximizes the excess of pleasure over pain.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Everybody is to count for one; and nobody for more than one.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The greatest happiness of the greatest number is the foundation of morals and legislation.
records.reference: ‘The Commonplace Book’ in Works (Editor: J. Bowring), Jeremy Bentham, 1843

records.line: All punishment is mischief: all punishment in itself is evil.
records.reference: Principles of Morals and Legislation, Jeremy Bentham, 1789

records.line: The question is not “Can they reason?” nor “Can they talk?” but “Can they suffer?”. The law should protect any sensitive being.
records.reference: Principles of Morals and Legislation, Jeremy Bentham, 1789

records.line: Government and all human relations can be simplified, explicated, and rendered transparent.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/wollstonecraft/, Author: Sylvana Tomaselli

records.line: God made all things right and the cause of all evil is man.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/wollstonecraft/, Author: Sylvana Tomaselli

records.line: Rights entail duties; none could be expected to perform duties whose natural rights are not respected.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/wollstonecraft/, Author: Sylvana Tomaselli

records.line: For a truly moral society, a complete change in the nature of the relationship between men and women is required.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/wollstonecraft/, Author: Sylvana Tomaselli

records.line: Women are ill-prepared for their duties as social beings and imprisoned in a web of false expectations.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/wollstonecraft/, Author: Sylvana Tomaselli

records.line: Women should be educated like men, to become rational and independent beings whose sense of worth doesn’t come from their appearance.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/wollstonecraft/, Author: Sylvana Tomaselli

records.line: Women should be able to support themselves and their children, and never have to marry or remarry out of financial necessity.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/wollstonecraft/, Author: Sylvana Tomaselli

records.line: Women should be granted civil and political rights; they should elect representatives of their own.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/wollstonecraft/, Author: Sylvana Tomaselli

records.line: Scientific laws cannot be deduced from empirical observations.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Empirical observations can be deduced from scientific laws.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The universe is a creation of the subject, with logical necessity, from our conception of it.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: We have experience of our existence, not as knowing subjects by introspection, but as moral agents.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: We know that we persist over time because we know that we bear moral responsibility.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The nature of all reality is moral; it is primarily created by our moral acts.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: All life is created by Nature out of lifeless matter.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Nature is a process, starting with dead matter, evolving into plants, animals, and then humans.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Everything is one; life is continuous with matter.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Man is part of Nature, not separate from or above it.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Man’s creativity is different from the rest of Nature’s creativity; it is self-aware.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Since man is part of Nature, in creative arts Nature is becoming self-aware.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The end-point of the process of Nature is self-awareness.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Creative art is the summit of all existence, the raison d’être of reality.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The final desperate question: Why is there anything at all? Why not nothing?
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Geist (spirit-mind) is the stuff of existence.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Everything is the result of an intelligible (not arbitrary) process of change, and everything is changing.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Reality is a historical process where Geist develops towards self-awareness.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Dialectical Process: Thesis (first stage) + Antithesis (reactions, conflicts) = Synthesis (a new thesis)
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Change is dominated by historical forces; the individual has no control, he must go with the flow (Zeitgeist).
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: When Geist will reach self-awareness, everything will be harmonious and change will stop (the Absolute).
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: In the Absolute, we will be free from conflict, happily serving the whole instead of our own interests.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Our institutions/rules/inventions become external constraints on us, alienating us from ourselves.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: We project qualities on to God (omniscience, etc.) that alienate us from Him whereas we are one.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: One’s self-consciousness is dependent on one’s recognition of those others as similarly recognizing oneself as a self-conscious subject.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/hegel/, Author: Paul Redding

records.line: Without time and space there can be no differentiation.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The noumenal reality, without time and space, cannot consist of things; it is one thing.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Causal connection can exist only within the phenomenal; noumena cannot cause phenomena.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Will and the bodily movements are the same events known in two different ways (from inside/outside).
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The phenomena in the universe requires a vast impersonal, unconscious energy without purpose.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The energy, the force, the impersonal ‘will’ that we see in the physical events is what noumenal is.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: In the phenomenal world, we seem to be separate but ultimately we are one in the noumenal.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The basis of morality is compassion because we are one and we share each other’s sufferings.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The concept of a personal God is too anthropomorphic to be taken seriously.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The concept of soul is useless; it supposes mind to be inseparably connected and yet independent of the organism.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The empirical world is without meaning and purpose.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The empirical world seems to be independent of ourselves, but in fact it is all subject-dependent – an illusion.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: We should not be taken by the empirical world; we should renounce it.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The end stage of philosophical understanding is the turning away of the human will from the world.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: We are slaves to our desires, never fully satisfied; existence is suffering.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: We can only escape existential suffering through aesthetic contemplation or asceticism.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Arts give us the experience of being taken out of time and space, out of ourselves.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Music transcends the others arts in metaphysical significance.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: God is an imaginary representation of the human species-essence; theology is anthropology.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/ludwig-feuerbach/, Author: Todd Gooch

records.line: When human beings in the course of their history acquire new and different wishes, they worship new and different divinities.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/ludwig-feuerbach/, Author: Todd Gooch

records.line: Religion is an alienated form of human self-consciousness: it involves the relation of us to our own essence as though to a being distinct from ourselves.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/ludwig-feuerbach/, Author: Todd Gooch

records.line: Theological claims understood in the usual sense (referring to a non-human divine person) are self-contradictory.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/ludwig-feuerbach/, Author: Todd Gooch

records.line: To posit matter as God is to affirm atheism and materialism.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/ludwig-feuerbach/, Author: Todd Gooch

records.line: We need to renounce the theological essence of religion to affirm its true anthropological essence: the divinity of man.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/ludwig-feuerbach/, Author: Todd Gooch

records.line: The hidden “truth of Christianity” will finally be realized as an atheistic humanism which embraces the historical tasks of human self-realization.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/ludwig-feuerbach/, Author: Todd Gooch

records.line: Thought comes from being, but being does not come from thought.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/ludwig-feuerbach/, Author: Todd Gooch

records.line: I am a real, sensuous being and the body in its totality is my ego, my essence itself.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/ludwig-feuerbach/, Author: Todd Gooch

records.line: When we are considering our policies, we should seek the greatest happiness of the greatest number.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The concept of freedom isn’t meaningful in the state of nature.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Freedom can flourish only where there are political and legal institutions protecting individual interests and public good.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: A person should be free to do anything as long as it doesn’t harm anyone else.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: There should exist the fullest liberty of professing and discussing any doctrine, however immoral it may be considered.
records.reference: On Liberty, John Stuart Mill,  John W.Parker & Son., 1859

records.line: Over his own body and mind, the individual is sovereign.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The inequality of men and women is a relic from the past; it should be replaced by a system of perfect equality.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The semantic value of a name is its referent.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/names/, Author: Sam Cumming

records.line: The sensation of color cannot be explained by any law of motion (of the particles in the body) even though there is correlation between the two.
records.reference: A System of Logic, John Stuart Mill, John W. Parker, 1843

records.line: All the organic beings which have ever lived on this earth have descended from some one primordial form.
records.reference: The Origin of Species, Charles Darwin, John Murray, 1859

records.line: There is one general law in the evolution of organisms: multiply, vary, let the best adapted live and the worst adapted die.
records.reference: The Origin of Species, Charles Darwin, John Murray, 1859

records.line: It is hardly possible to define clearly what is meant by the organisation of a living thing being higher or lower.
records.reference: The Origin of Species, Charles Darwin, John Murray, 1859

records.line: ‘Species’ is an artificial concept made for convenience; the search for the essence of the term ‘species’ is in vain.
records.reference: The Origin of Species, Charles Darwin, John Murray, 1859

records.line: The gradual formation of different languages is similar to that of species; the survival of favored words is natural selection.
records.reference: The Descent of Man, Charles Darwin, John Murray, 1871

records.line: The study of nature and man will become far more interesting when we regard every production of nature as one which has had a history.
records.reference: The Origin of Species, Charles Darwin, John Murray, 1859

records.line: We have to look at individual entities, not ideas, to understand the world.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The individual human being is the ultimate moral actor; our personal lives, our decisions are important.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: We build our lives and ourselves through the choices we make.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The relationship of the individual soul to God is what matters most.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The supreme paradox of all thought is the attempt to discover something that thought cannot think.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Reality is a historical dialectical process operating with alienations.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Only when alienations end will we be free and in control, as parts of an organic society instead of selfish individuals.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The world and the dialectical process of change consist of material (not spiritual) forces.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The dialectic works with the development of the means of production and the conflicts between social classes.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Institutions, religions, philosophies, the arts, etc. are determined by the economic substructure.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Religion is man-made; it is the opium of the people.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The Industrialist Capitalist society is the last stage before the end of history, of the dialectic.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The development of technology (belonging to few) is alienating people from the means of production.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The workers will overthrow the capitalists and create a class-free society where the means of production belong to all.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Knowledge is an activity: a process of doubt/need-to-know, evaluation, and understanding/explaining.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: A term whose application makes no difference has no ascertainable meaning – meaning is functional.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Knowledge is an instrument of survival in this world; we acquire it as participants, not as spectators.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Scientific activity isn’t adding new certainties to existing ones; it’s replacing old explanations with better ones.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Truth is the final opinion on which inquiry is fated to converge.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Knowledge that does all the jobs required of it (fit the known facts, generate insights/predictions, etc.) is true.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: If a statement cannot be disproved and a person benefits from believing in it, he is justified in doing so.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: There is no God and we do not have immortal souls.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: We are driven by our wills in this meaningless world full of suffering.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: This world is all there is – we should embrace it.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Our current ethics is based on old societies and religions; we should find new foundations for ethics.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Our success as a species was due to the elimination of the weak (stupid, etc.) by the strong (clever, etc.).
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Moralists like Jesus created slave-moralities – mediocracies protecting the weak and oppressing the gifted.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The gifted should be able to actualize their ‘will to power’ in every domain – in politics, in arts, etc.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The will to power is the true happiness for superior people, which is also in the interest of mankind.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: We should embrace a new ethics of life-assertion, allowing the superior to become supermen.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: We should not fear conflict with others; it makes us develop our abilities.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: A life lived to the full doesn’t need to derive its meaning from outside itself.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Everything that has happened will happen again in cosmic epicycles of time; this can give motivation for life.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Logic is independent of human thought; we can learn it, but it’s not ‘laws of thought’.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Mathematics can be derived from logic.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The ‘reference’ of an expression is the actual thing corresponding to it – its truth value if it is a proposition.
records.reference: ‘On Sense and Reference’, Gottlob Frege, 1892

records.line: The ‘sense’ of an expression is the ‘mode of presentation’ by which one conceives of the reference, whether or not it exists.
records.reference: ‘On Sense and Reference’, Gottlob Frege, 1892

records.line: Expressions with different senses can have the same reference.
records.reference: ‘On Sense and Reference’, Gottlob Frege, 1892

records.line: There is a dynamic unconscious part of the mind which exerts pressures and influences on what we do and say.
records.reference: Seven Theories of Human Nature, Leslie Stevenson, Oxford University Press, 1974

records.line: The ‘unconscious’ is different from the ‘preconscious’ (some memories, facts, etc.) which can become conscious.
records.reference: Seven Theories of Human Nature, Leslie Stevenson, Oxford University Press, 1974

records.line: The human mind has three structural systems: the ‘id’ (instincts), the ‘ego’ (the reconciler), and the ‘super-ego’ (conscience).
records.reference: Seven Theories of Human Nature, Leslie Stevenson, Oxford University Press, 1974

records.line: All the “energy” in our minds comes from the instincts alone.
records.reference: Seven Theories of Human Nature, Leslie Stevenson, Oxford University Press, 1974

records.line: The ‘Life’ instinct (Eros) contains erotic and self-preservative instincts; the ‘Death’ instinct (Thanatos) contains sadism, aggression, self-harm, etc.
records.reference: Seven Theories of Human Nature, Leslie Stevenson, Oxford University Press, 1974

records.line: Our adult characters are determined by our early childhood experiences which have many sexual (body-pleasure-related) elements.
records.reference: Seven Theories of Human Nature, Leslie Stevenson, Oxford University Press, 1974

records.line: When we repress our inner conflicts, they continue to exist in the unconscious and create neurotic symptoms.
records.reference: Seven Theories of Human Nature, Leslie Stevenson, Oxford University Press, 1974

records.line: Neurosis can sometimes be treated with psychoanalysis: a process that brings back the repressed material into consciousness.
records.reference: Seven Theories of Human Nature, Leslie Stevenson, Oxford University Press, 1974

records.line: Our whole civilized life might be neurotic because of the sacrifice of instinctual satisfaction.
records.reference: Seven Theories of Human Nature, Leslie Stevenson, Oxford University Press, 1974

records.line: The teachings of religion are illusions whose reality value cannot be assessed; just as they are unverifiable, they are also irrefutable.
records.reference: The Future of an Illusion, Sigmund Freud, 1927

records.line: To use private judgement about religious arguments would be a wanton undertaking; such questions are too significant for that.
records.reference: The Future of an Illusion, Sigmund Freud, 1927

records.line: The God that many philosophers define is no more than an insubstantial shadow, no longer the mighty figure of religious teaching.
records.reference: The Future of an Illusion, Sigmund Freud, 1927

records.line: The truths contained in religion are so distorted and symbolically disguised that most people are incapable of recognizing them as truth.
records.reference: The Future of an Illusion, Sigmund Freud, 1927

records.line: Our mental apparatus was in fact developed in the effort to map the outside world, so must have a certain amount of expediency in its structure.
records.reference: The Future of an Illusion, Sigmund Freud, 1927

records.line: A language (‘langue’) is the virtual system possessed by all those who form part of the same speech community.
records.reference: Oxford Research Encyclopedias, https://bit.ly/2PcI6wg, Author: John E. Joseph

records.line: ‘La parole’ is the utterances, the texts, that individuals produce and understand making use of the system that is ‘la langue’.
records.reference: Oxford Research Encyclopedias, https://bit.ly/2PcI6wg, Author: John E. Joseph

records.line: It is not things, but our conception of things, that are part of our language: schemas in the brain being evoked by certain combinations of sounds.
records.reference: Oxford Research Encyclopedias, https://bit.ly/2PcI6wg, Author: John E. Joseph

records.line: A language is a system of signs, each composed of two entirely mental values: ‘signifier’ (sound pattern) and ‘signified’ (concept).
records.reference: Oxford Research Encyclopedias, https://bit.ly/2PcI6wg, Author: John E. Joseph

records.line: Each signifier and each signified is a value produced by the difference between it and all the other signifiers and signifieds in the system.
records.reference: Oxford Research Encyclopedias, https://bit.ly/2PcI6wg, Author: John E. Joseph

records.line: The conjunction of signifier and signified is a sign which is of a positive order, and is concrete rather than abstract.
records.reference: Oxford Research Encyclopedias, https://bit.ly/2PcI6wg, Author: John E. Joseph

records.line: Every word or term or unit within the system is connected to an entourage of other units; no linguistic sign exists in isolation.
records.reference: Oxford Research Encyclopedias, https://bit.ly/2PcI6wg, Author: John E. Joseph

records.line: The link between a signifier and a signified is radically arbitrary; there is no logical connection between them.
records.reference: Oxford Research Encyclopedias, https://bit.ly/2PcI6wg, Author: John E. Joseph

records.line: Every element of a language is subject to change, to evolution, but no individual can change it.
records.reference: Oxford Research Encyclopedias, https://bit.ly/2PcI6wg, Author: John E. Joseph

records.line: Both the mutability and the immutability of language result from the arbitrariness of the sign.
records.reference: Oxford Research Encyclopedias, https://bit.ly/2PcI6wg, Author: John E. Joseph

records.line: Before language, human thought was an amorphous, indistinct, nebulous mass, a floating realm; and human sound was no different.
records.reference: Oxford Research Encyclopedias, https://bit.ly/2PcI6wg, Author: John E. Joseph

records.line: Language and writing are two distinct systems of signs; the second exists for the sole purpose of representing the first.
records.reference: Course in General Linguistics, Ferdinand de Saussure, 1916

records.line: The one thing that exists for sure is our consciousness; we should start from there to build our picture of reality.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Our awareness is of objects, but not of ourselves.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Intersubjective (empathic) experience occurs when we consciously attribute intentional acts to other subjects.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/husserl/, Author: Christian Beyer

records.line: In intersubjective experience, I must presuppose that the objects forming my own world exist independently of my subjective perspective.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/husserl/, Author: Christian Beyer

records.line: Intersubjectivity is crucial in our constitution of ourselves as objectively existing subjects, other subjects, and the objective world.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/husserl/, Author: Christian Beyer

records.line: Human beings should be explained from the perspective of evolution.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Our senses do not give us objective representations; they stimulate behavior for survival.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Evolution is directed by a drive (‘élan vital’) towards greater individuality and complexity.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Everything changes; time is fundamental to reality, to life.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: We have direct intuitive experience of time, independent of conceptual thinking and sensual input.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: We know we have free will because we have direct intuitive knowledge about our decisions to act.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Our intellect artificially breaks up time and space into manageable units to handle them.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The partitioning of the world is very useful for everyday life, business, and science (predicting and controlling).
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The partitioning of the world does not show us reality; real time and space are continuous.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: We live in two worlds: our inner experience of the continuum, and our intellect’s partitioning.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Knowledge is an adaptive human response to environing conditions, with practical instrumentality in the control of that interaction.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/dewey/, Author: Richard Field

records.line: Scientific knowledge is the most reliable and useful type of knowledge.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: There is no fundamental fact/value distinction; nature embraces all aspects of life, including values.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: The problem-solving approach of the scientific method should be the pattern for all other types of enquiry.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The scientific method is a social activity because it requires criticism.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The education of children should be based on the problem-solving approach (‘learning by doing’).
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Scientific hypotheses only work given further auxiliary hypotheses, some of which are about the experimental equipment.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Observations and experiments cannot be by themselves decisive in refuting scientific hypotheses.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: When a prediction fails, the scientist may reconsider the theoretical postulates or check the equipment.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Mathematics can be derived from logic.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: All knowledge of the external world is derived from experience.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: We can generate knowledge with absolute certainty by applying logical analysis to our statements.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Logical analysis of language can clarify, and in some cases resolve, questions of philosophy.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: A description is not a name; a sentence can be meaningful (and true/false) even if a description in it fails to describe anything.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Ordinary proper names are in fact disguised descriptions.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Immense harm is caused by the belief that work is virtuous; working less will increase human happiness.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: We are more certain of the truth of everyday things than we are of the general grounds for doubt introduced by sceptics.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: We can regard the unbelievable conclusions of sceptical arguments as reasons for rejecting their premises.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Moral concepts are neither reducible to nor derivable from non-moral (scientific or metaphysical) judgements. (‘naturalistic fallacy’)
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/moore-moral/, Author: Thomas Hurka

records.line: Morality presupposes the existence of an irreducible domain of distinctive and objective facts about the intrinsic value of different things.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Ethical knowledge rests on a capacity for an intuitive grasp of fundamental ethical truths.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/moore/, Author: Thomas Baldwin

records.line: We cannot even talk about the part of reality beyond our experience – that talk becomes nonsense.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: We can talk about and try to understand the phenomenal world of experience.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Our understanding of the world is based on language.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The limits of language define the limits of our conception – what we can understand about the world.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Language is like a picture, describing reality by having the same logical form with it.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Language is a multifunctional tool; meaning is not static, it depends on the context and the function being served.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Language is a public, social thing, getting its meanings from language-games; there can be no private language.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Objective truth is not the privileged achievement of any one language-game, such as the natural sciences.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: I have insufficient distance with my sensations to doubt them, so talk of knowledge about sensations makes no sense.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Our talk of sensations and other mental states is expressive, not descriptive.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Philosophy has nothing to contribute with the empirical problems; they are to be solved by empirical methods.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Much of philosophy consist of confusions created by a misuse of language.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The philosopher’s job should be to eliminate the conceptual confusions by an analysis of language.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Our common-sense understanding provides the context within which doubts are possible; scepticism is self-undermining.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: We are part of the world we investigate; the real problem is not knowledge but being, existence.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998
