records.line: To address the problem of existence, we should analyze our consciousness which certainly exists.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Our being is three-fold, with elements corresponding to past, present, and future: being is time.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: When we are born, we find ourselves in the world as if we had been thrown there on a trajectory we have not chosen.
records.reference: The Philosophy Book, DK Pub., 2011

records.line: From the start we exist in a social context; we strive to become individuals with a personal existence.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: We are always faced with decisions about an unknown future, and the anxiety in the face of death.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: We want our lives to have meaning or some metaphysical feature, but we are not sure if these exist.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Ultimately our lives may be meaningless; or meaning may just be anything we create.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: We exist inauthentically when we get wrapped up in our daily projects and forget about death.
records.reference: The Philosophy Book, DK Pub., 2011

records.line: ‘Destruktion’ of the social traditions can lead us back to a past that reveals the deeper understanding of Being.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/deconst/, Author: Nancy J. Holland

records.line: Human beings are beings of excess with exorbitant energy, fantasies, drives, needs, and heterogeneous desire.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/baudrillard/, Author: Douglas Kellner

records.line: The capitalist imperatives of labor, utility, and savings are unnatural, and go against human nature.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/baudrillard/, Author: Douglas Kellner

records.line: We can escape the existing imperatives of utility (capitalism) by pursuing a ‘general economy’ of expenditure, giving, sacrifice, and destruction.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/baudrillard/, Author: Douglas Kellner

records.line: All legitimate knowledge is either scientific or logico-mathematical.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: The proper activity left over for philosophy is only a method: the method of logical analysis.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: The truths of logic are a by-product of the meaning of the language we use for reasoning and calculation.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: The truth of even what are supposed to be analytic truths may require revision in the light of experience.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Analyticity should be defined within ‘linguistic frameworks’ describing a subject-matter (physics, astronomy, etc.).
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: The main aim of science is explanation.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: A good scientific explanation is one that would have enabled the phenomenon to be predicted.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: The logic of science is a combination of the deductive refutation and the inductive confirmation of theoretical predictions by observation.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: The progress of science consists in the refinement of unrefuted theories.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Predictions of a theory should be couched in an ‘observation-language’ whose meaning is independent of the theory.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Theories which include reference to unobservable things are merely instruments for calculation.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Physical reality is of a very different nature from the human experience, and cannot be directly understood.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Theories cannot be proved, but they can be disproved; criticism is the main method of progress.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Theories are ‘corroborated’ when they survive several refutations; the better corroborated it is, the more it approximates to the truth.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: The progress of science consists in the replacement of refuted theories by theories that are only tentatively corroborated.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: A statement that cannot be falsified by any observation is not scientific.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The observations and experiments which test scientific theories are not independent of scientific theory.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Unobservable things postulated by scientific theories are not intrinsically different from observable things.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Certainty is not possible in politics; the imposition of a single viewpoint is never justified.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Centralized planning without criticism is the most undesirable form of society.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: A perfect static society is a dream; we can only engage in perpetual improvement, reducing social evils.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The analytical techniques of formal logic cannot resolve philosophical problems.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Materialist mechanism cannot by itself explain mental phenomena; human affairs need explanations of different kinds and levels.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Cartesian dualism (‘ghost in the machine’) is a category mistake.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Our talk of “the mind” does not require the existence of a private space within which mental acts and happenings take place.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Having a mind is a matter of possessing abilities (knowing how to do things), dispositions, inclinations (emotions).
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: When we perceive or have sensations, we are attending to features of the world or of our bodies, not to our experiences.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: If our experiences have to be attended by us, that awareness experience also has to be attended – this sets off an absurd regress.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: We can choose to attend to the experiences of perception/sensation, but it will be retrospective and fallible.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Our first-person statements about intentions and decisions are ‘avowels’ and not descriptions of our mental states.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: The self is elusive; when we try to attend to ourselves, we put ourselves beyond our reach.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: A belief is justified if it was obtained by a process which is reliable.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Inductive arguments are justified insofar as the world is so constituted that they lead on the whole to true opinions.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: In the recognition of its mirror-image, the child is having its first anticipation of itself as a unified and separate individual.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/lacweb/, Author: Matthew Sharpe

records.line: The ‘I’ is an ‘other’ from the ground up: an artificial projection of subjective unity modelled on how one is seen from other perspectives.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/lacweb/, Author: Matthew Sharpe

records.line: ‘The Imaginary’ is our quotidian reality: who and what one imagines other persons to be, who and what one imagines oneself to be, etc.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/lacan/, Author: Adrian Johnston

records.line: ‘The Symbolic’ is the customs, institutions, laws, mores, etc. of cultures and societies (the ‘Other’), entwined with language.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/lacan/, Author: Adrian Johnston

records.line: ‘The Real’ is whatever is beyond phenomenal appearances; it is intrinsically elusive and uncapturable by Imaginary-Symbolic signs.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/lacan/, Author: Adrian Johnston

records.line: The insertion into socio-symbolic contexts and the dependence on the foreignness of signifiers amount to a ‘symbolic castration’.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/lacan/, Author: Adrian Johnston

records.line: ‘Master signifiers’ (those that the subject most deeply identifies with, like nationality) are actually signifiers without a signified.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/lacweb/, Author: Matthew Sharpe

records.line: The unconscious is not an anarchic bundle of animalistic instincts like the id – it is structured like language.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/lacan/, Author: Adrian Johnston

records.line: Demand – need = desire: vital requirements take on the excess baggage of meanings and become socio-symbolic demands for love.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/lacan/, Author: Adrian Johnston

records.line: ‘Drive’ extracts enjoyment (‘jouissance’) from the dissatisfactions of desire, sometimes through repetitive or overwhelming experiences.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/lacan/, Author: Adrian Johnston

records.line: The Real of sexuation creates incommensurable structural-psychical positions for the sexes; there is no sexual relationship.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/lacan/, Author: Adrian Johnston

records.line: There is no such thing as pure thought: thinking is a socio-historical form of activity, and there is not a universal standpoint to discern “truth”.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/adorno/, Author: Andrew Fagan

records.line: ‘Identity thinking’ is misrepresenting reality by putting specific phenomena under general, abstract classificatory headings.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/adorno/, Author: Andrew Fagan

records.line: ‘Identity thinking’ is fundamentally concerned not to understand phenomena but to control and manipulate it.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/adorno/, Author: Andrew Fagan

records.line: The source of today’s disaster is the domination of nature and human beings by other human beings.
records.reference: (& Horkheimer) Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/adorno/, Author: Lambert Zuidervaart

records.line: A critique of modernity must also be a critique of premodernity; a turn toward the postmodern cannot simply be a return to the premodern.
records.reference: (& Horkheimer) Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/adorno/, Author: Lambert Zuidervaart

records.line: The instrumentalization of reason and the supremacy of “facts” established a single order: enlightenment is totalitarian (like myth).
records.reference: (& Horkheimer) The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/adorno/, Author: Andrew Fagan

records.line: With the instrumentalization of reason and positivism, morality is put under the invalid, “meaningless” category of subjective knowledge.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/adorno/, Author: Andrew Fagan

records.line: Intelligence is a moral category; the separation of feeling and understanding dismembers man into function.
records.reference: Minima Moralia, Theodor Adorno, 1951

records.line: The ‘culture industry’ promotes domination by subverting the psychological development of the mass of people in capitalist societies.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/adorno/, Author: Andrew Fagan

records.line: The commodities of the culture industry are increasingly standardized, formulaic, and repetitive in character.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/adorno/, Author: Andrew Fagan

records.line: The standardization of music promotes a general condition of immaturity, prohibiting the exercise of any critical or reflexive faculties.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/adorno/, Author: Andrew Fagan

records.line: The appeal of totalitarian ideologies rests upon the devastation of ordered and stable contexts in which people once lived.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/arendt/, Author: Majid Yar

records.line: There are three types of human activities: labor, work, and action (in ascending hierarchy of importance).
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/arendt/, Author: Majid Yar

records.line: Labor is the biological practices necessary for the maintenance of life: an animal-like, unfree, private activity with impermanent products.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/arendt/, Author: Majid Yar

records.line: Work is the fabrication of quasi-permanent physical and cultural artifacts: a non-animal, public activity with some degree of freedom.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/arendt/, Author: Majid Yar

records.line: The rise of ‘animal laborans’ threatens the extinction of ‘homo faber’ and what makes a community’s public life possible (‘world alienation’).
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/arendt/, Author: Majid Yar

records.line: Authentic human action can initiate the wholly new – unanticipated, unconditioned by the laws of cause and effect.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/arendt/, Author: Majid Yar

records.line: Actions cannot be justified for their own sake, but only in light of their public recognition and the shared rules of a political community.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/arendt/, Author: Majid Yar

records.line: The raison d’être of politics is freedom, and its field of experience is action.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/arendt/, Author: Majid Yar

records.line: Evil does not come from malevolence, but from failures of thinking and judgement, sometimes abused by oppressive political systems.
records.reference: The Philosophy Book, DK Pub., 2011

records.line: A disinterested and imaginatively publicly-minded form of political judgement is required to tackle the new circumstances of the modern era.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/arendt/, Author: Majid Yar

records.line: The object of consciousness exists in an independent way; however, consciousness itself is always consciousness “of something.”
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/sartre-ex/, Author: Christian J. Onof

records.line: Since other minds are required to account for conscious states such as those of shame, this establishes their existence a priori.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/sartre-ex/, Author: Christian J. Onof

records.line: The objectification of the other corresponds to an affirmation of my self by distinguishing myself from the other.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/sartre-ex/, Author: Christian J. Onof

records.line: When I objectify the other, I deny its selfhood and therefore deny that with respect to which I want to affirm myself.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/sartre-ex/, Author: Christian J. Onof

records.line: The instability of the dependence upon the other is characteristic of the typically conflictual state of our relations with others.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/sartre-ex/, Author: Christian J. Onof

records.line: In this Godless world we are thrown into, we are condemned to be free and to create our own values.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Existence precedes essence; by choosing our values we determine the nature of our lives and personalities, we create ourselves.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The freedom can be terrifying; many run away from it and choose existing norms. (‘bad faith’)
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Woman is consistently defined as the Other by man who takes on the role of the Self.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/beauvoir/, Author: Shannon Mussett

records.line: Men have been privileged with expressing transcendence through projects; women have been forced into the uncreative life of immanence.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/beauvoir/, Author: Shannon Mussett

records.line: Biology and history are not mere “facts” of an unbiased observer, but are always incorporated into and interpreted from a situation.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/beauvoir/, Author: Shannon Mussett

records.line: The myth of the ‘Eternal Feminine’ (the mother, the virgin, the motherland, nature, etc.) traps women into an impossible ideal by denying their individuality.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/beauvoir/, Author: Shannon Mussett

records.line: One is not born, but rather becomes, a woman – constructed to be such through social indoctrination.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/beauvoir/, Author: Shannon Mussett

records.line: Many women living in patriarchal cultures are guilty of ‘bad faith’; they flee their responsibility into prefabricated values and beliefs.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/beauvoir/, Author: Shannon Mussett

records.line: Social systems must be altered for equal treatment of women, but women themselves also should take on their existential responsibility.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/beauvoir/, Author: Shannon Mussett

records.line: It is absurd that we ask for meaning for our lives in a universe without meaning and purpose.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The Absurd is not in man nor in the world, but in their presence together; it is the only bond uniting them.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/camus/, Author: David Simpson

records.line: There is but one truly serious philosophical problem and that is suicide.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: To kill oneself is a capitulation; we should refuse to surrender unto the meaninglessness of the universe.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The religious solution of positing a transcendent world of solace and meaning beyond the Absurd is philosophical suicide.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/camus/, Author: David Simpson

records.line: The only authentic and valid solution to the Absurd is simply to accept it, or better yet to embrace it, and to continue living. (‘Revolt’)
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/camus/, Author: David Simpson

records.line: True revolt is performed not just for the self but also in solidarity with and out of compassion for others.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/camus/, Author: David Simpson

records.line: An analysis of rebellion leads at least to the suspicion that, contrary to contemporary thought, a human nature does exist.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/camus/, Author: David Simpson

records.line: We are not immaterial centers of consciousness; we cannot perceive or act without our bodies.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: Each one of us has a unique position in space and time which affects how we experience the world.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: The human body is an object and a subject at the same time.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: All traditional metaphysical statements, including religious ones, are meaningless.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Beliefs about material objects are never absolutely certain; beliefs concerning their appearances (our sense-data) are.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: We should use sense-data as the primary objects of perception to provide ourselves with foundations for our knowledge of the world.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: The only way to give meaning to ethics is to interpret ethical statements as expressions of emotions (disgust, delight, etc.).
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: A moral philosopher’s concern is not primarily to make moral judgements but to analyze their nature.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Ordinary language embodies the inherited experience and acumen of many generations; it is not the last word, but it is the first word.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: For the objects of perception, the reality-appearance duality is misconceived; the term ‘real’ has many different uses.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: The application of the positive term (reality, freedom, etc.) depends on its negative term, which is itself contextual.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: The search for absolute certainty is both fruitless and unwanted.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Because a belief is about something, its truth is independent of the fact that it is believed; it must be possible for the thinker to be mistaken.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: What is evidence for what is always contextual; there is no limit to the kinds of evidence that might turn out to be relevant.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: There can’t be a theory providing an abstract recipe for the totality of evidence for a particular claim.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: In sceptical arguments we should locate our doubts only in specific contexts of inquiry.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Utterances are not always descriptions; they can be ‘performatives’ in which we do things with words (promises, threats, etc.).
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Three types of speech act: locutionary (what I say), illocutionary (what I do in saying that), perlocutionary (what effect it has on the listener).
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Claims to knowledge (“I know that S is P”) can also be performatives where we give others our authority (for saying that S is P).
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: There is no way to define analyticity without an appeal to synonymy defined analytically; it’s a vicious circle.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: There are no principled limits to the range of evidence for a statement; evidence and understanding are holistic.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Nothing, including putative conceptual truths, logic, and mathematics, is immune from revision in the light of experience.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: There aren’t any analytic truths; all truths are of the same kind, dependent both on language and on the state of the world.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Philosophy should be naturalized, placed within the understanding provided by natural sciences.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: There is redundancy in our belief networks, so we can question one part without compromising all the rest.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Discrimination of meaning needs evidence from the linguistic behaviour of the speakers.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Translation between languages is underdetermined: there are multiple equally good translations.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Indeterminacy of translation implies indeterminacy of communication, even of thinking.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Necessity (essentialism) inheres in some of our ways of speaking of things, not in the properties of things themselves.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: External moral requirements are ‘justifying’ reasons for action, different from internal ‘motivating’ reasons.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: We should be stereoscopic with the ‘scientific image’ and the ‘manifest image’ of the world.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: The manifest image is the framework in which we first came to be aware of ourselves as persons.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: The conception of the physical world characteristic of the manifest image is incorrect insofar as it conflicts with the scientific image.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: The concept of knowledge exists in the ‘logical space of reasons’, the domain of the manifest image.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Sense-experience (‘the Given’) cannot guarantee the authenticity of information but it can cause us to form reliable beliefs.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: We can use the analogy of brain states as sentence-like structures and translate them into our own language to assess them rationally.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: The meaning of a referring expression and its referent in a particular context are separate things.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: A sentence with a vacuous referring expression is meaningful, but is not a statement (true or false).
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: There is a distinction between the contextual presuppositions of a sentence and its logical implications.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Sceptical doubts amount to the rejection of the whole conceptual scheme within which such doubt make sense.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Self-consciousness requires that there is a distinction between ourselves and others; thus, others really exist.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: The basic structure of our conceptual scheme lies so deep in our thought and practice that its legitimation is neither possible nor necessary.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: The primitive concept of a person allows us to see human life with physical and (irreducible) mental aspects without being dualistic.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: The ‘conversational implicature’ of an utterance can be different from its strict meaning; it is central to humour, rudeness, etc.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Intentions are transmitted perlocutionarily, by an effect produced by the speaker on the listener, exterior to linguistic conventions.
records.reference: Derrida/Searle, Raoul Moati, Columbia University Press, 2014

records.line: Actions are identified and understood by reference to the intentions with which they were performed.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: The ‘practical knowledge’ of action is different from the ‘contemplative’ knowledge of science.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Unintentional causes of action (‘mental causes’) are not reasons for action.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Thinking of morality as a set of rules prescribing what we “ought” to do presupposes a religious conception about what is “owed” to God.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: A secular culture should construct a new morality based on our understanding of particular virtues and vices.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: A secular morality requires a new philosophy of mind which will break with the old ways of thinking about the roles of beliefs and desires in explaining action.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: The practice of the virtues should connect with a potentiality for ‘human flourishing’.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Utilitarianism cannot sustain any strict prohibitions because it cannot distinguish between intended and merely foreseen consequences.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Intention and action are not distinct existences; reasons are not causes.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: The relationship between an action and a reason does not have to be the same every time and for every agent, unlike a causal relationship.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: The study of society is about the logical relationships between the beliefs and intentions, and the rules of social institutions.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Social studies are not causal inquiries; there cannot be a social science.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: The truth-conditions of a sentence should be used to provide its meaning.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: We get to meaning by interpreting others, by presuming that their beliefs are largely true and that they are generally rational.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Language isn’t a network of social conventions; there are just the general grammatical capacities and individual communicative strategies.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Languages provide ways of thinking about and expressing truths about this world, so they are translatable.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: One cannot be a thinker at all unless one has beliefs.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: One cannot have a belief unless one recognizes that one might be in error.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: It is only through seeing others’ errors that one can understand the possibility of being in error oneself.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: A creature cannot have thoughts unless it is an interpreter of the speech of another; “no thought without talk.”
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Mental states ‘supervene’ on physical states: there cannot be two events alike in all physical respects but differing in mental respects.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: There is no general strict law connecting physical descriptions of states with mental descriptions of them.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Reasons and actions are in causal relationships in their physical states.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Actions cannot be causally determined; the free will debate should not arise at all.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Our ordinary moral thought embodies a commitment to the reality of moral values.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: No real moral facts exist; they are impossibly ‘queer’.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: The variety of moral practices in history and anthropology shows that there is no underlying moral reality.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Ethics is the logical study of the language of morals.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: There is a logical distinction between facts and values; morality is ‘prescriptive’ and is not a domain of moral facts to be ‘described’.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Moral imperatives are instances of principles that we are prepared to universalize.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Imaginative identification with others reveals principles that provide the best ways of fulfilling the preferences of all those who might be affected.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Imperatives with no relevance to the satisfaction of human interests do not become moral requirements simply by being universally prescribed.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Description and prescription are not separate in morality; value-judgements enter into descriptions.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Moral and political philosophy have no place for a rigid analytic/synthetic distinction.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: The construction of justice is guided by our recognition of a range of primary, fundamental goods.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: If the plurality of persons with separate ends is an essential feature of societies, the principles of social choice cannot be utilitarian.
records.reference: A Theory of Justice, John Rawls, Harvard University Press, 1971

records.line: The principles of justice should be chosen behind a ‘veil of ignorance’.
records.reference: A Theory of Justice, John Rawls, Harvard University Press, 1971

records.line: Each person is to have an equal right to the most extensive total system of equal basic liberties compatible with a similar system of liberty for all.
records.reference: A Theory of Justice, John Rawls, Harvard University Press, 1971

records.line: Social and economic inequalities are to be arranged so that they are to the greatest benefit of the least advantaged.
records.reference: A Theory of Justice, John Rawls, Harvard University Press, 1971

records.line: Offices and positions must be open to all under conditions of fair equality of opportunity.
records.reference: A Theory of Justice, John Rawls, Harvard University Press, 1971

records.line: Logic and observation are not enough to understand how science unfolds; we must look to its history.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Sciences alternate between periods of ‘normal science’ and periods of ‘crisis’ followed by ‘revolution’.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: It's only when a paradigm is established that empirical underdetermination is solved and normal science is possible.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: The paradigms eventually use up their capacity to solve empirical puzzles, and are replaced by new paradigms.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: A new paradigm is ‘incommensurable’ with the old one; there is no uncontested evidence and shared nomenclature to choose one.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: A procedure of judgement by the scientific community is required for paradigm-choice.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: There is no absolute distinction between the context of discovery and the context of justification.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: We may have to relinquish the notion that paradigm changes carry scientists closer and closer to the truth.
records.reference: The Structure of Scientific Revolutions, Thomas Kuhn, The University of Chicago Press, 1962

records.line: The development of science is like biological evolution: an increase in articulation and specialization, without an end goal.
records.reference: The Structure of Scientific Revolutions, Thomas Kuhn, The University of Chicago Press, 1962

records.line: We cannot just confront a theory with “the observed facts”; the identity and the significance of these facts are underdetermined.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: The history of science includes revolutions; ‘incommensurable’ alternatives replace existing theories.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/incommensurability/, Authors: Eric Oberheim & Paul Hoyningen-Huene

records.line: Science flourishes best when there is a proliferation of different paradigms (‘epistemological anarchism’).
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: The applications of our concepts and words change over time; we need an archaeology of our thinking.
records.reference: The Philosophy Book, DK Pub., 2011

records.line: The concept of ‘man’ is a recent invention, arising at the beginning of the 19th century, and it may be close to its end.
records.reference: The Philosophy Book, DK Pub., 2011

records.line: ‘Man’ is a paradoxical idea, seen both as object and subject.
records.reference: The Philosophy Book, DK Pub., 2011

records.line: Every kind of discourse is an attempt to exercise power over others.
records.reference: The Story of Philosophy, Bryan Magee, DK Pub., 1998

records.line: There are three primary techniques of control: hierarchical observation, normalizing judgment, and the examination.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/foucault/, Authors: Gary Gutting & Johanna Oksala

records.line: The modern prison is a model for factories, hospitals, and schools; a model to control an entire society.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/foucault/, Authors: Gary Gutting & Johanna Oksala

records.line: The categories of maleness and femaleness were founded and explained as “natural” in discourses claiming the status of scientific truth.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/foucault/, Authors: Gary Gutting & Johanna Oksala

records.line: The mission to liberate our repressed sexuality is misguided because there is no authentic or natural sexuality to liberate.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/foucault/, Authors: Gary Gutting & Johanna Oksala

records.line: Power is not repressive but productive; it produces, by cultural practices and scientific discourses, the ways we conceive of our sexuality.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/foucault/, Authors: Gary Gutting & Johanna Oksala

records.line: Individuals internalize the norms laid down by the sciences of sexuality and monitor themselves to conform to these norms.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/foucault/, Authors: Gary Gutting & Johanna Oksala

records.line: We should analyze power relations from the bottom up (families, workplaces, etc.) instead of looking for a center of power.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/foucault/, Authors: Gary Gutting & Johanna Oksala

records.line: One way of contesting power is by shaping oneself creatively, with new ways of being, new fields of experience, pleasures, relationships, etc.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/foucault/, Authors: Gary Gutting & Johanna Oksala

records.line: With computers, knowledge has become information that can be stored in databases, and bought and sold.
records.reference: The Philosophy Book, DK Pub., 2011

records.line: Knowledge is becoming externalized; it is no longer something that helps towards the development of minds.
records.reference: The Philosophy Book, DK Pub., 2011

records.line: Knowledge is becoming disconnected from questions of truth; it becomes a commodity.
records.reference: The Philosophy Book, DK Pub., 2011

records.line: Postmodernism is incredulity towards meta-narratives – overarching stories that put all of our knowledge into a single framework.
records.reference: The Philosophy Book, DK Pub., 2011

records.line: In the computer age the question of knowledge is now more than ever a question of government, of power.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/lyotard/, Author: Ashley Woodward

records.line: Science does not have any justification in claiming to be a more legitimate form of knowledge than narrative.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/lyotard/, Author: Ashley Woodward

records.line: The principle of performativity (efficiency) merely subordinates science to capital.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/lyotard/, Author: Ashley Woodward

records.line: Postmodern science is about the generation of new ideas rather than the efficient application of existing knowledge.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/lyotard/, Author: Ashley Woodward

records.line: Modern art presents the fact that there is an unpresentable, while postmodern art attempts to present the unpresentable, creating the sublime.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/lyotard/, Author: Ashley Woodward

records.line: A speaker’s understanding of her own language comprises an ability to conceptualize the world.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Psychology and linguistics can offer causal theories of language, but language is best seen as an activity of rational agents.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Understanding one aspect of language doesn’t require an understanding of the rest of it.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Words have meaning only insofar as they contribute to the meaning of sentences.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Communication is of the essence of language.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Understanding is based upon sensitivity to direct, canonical evidence for sentences, which is limited.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Speakers internalize conventional rules that are social norms; understanding requires reference to this social context.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Reality is constrained by the possibility of knowledge of it; it has gaps because the truths of some sentences are undecidable.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: The meaning of a concept depends on its role in a network (‘cluster’) of concepts, which can change in the light of experience.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: The identities of our thoughts are not purely psychological; they are affected by their worldly context.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Our scientific knowledge allows us to reach essentialist hypotheses such as “Water = H₂O”.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: One cannot refer to things if one has no causal interaction at all with them, or with things in terms of which they are described.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: A brain in a vat being deceived by mad scientists cannot think of brains or vats; they play no part in explaining its neural inputs.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: We cannot be brains in vats being deceived by mad scientists, because we can think of brains in vats.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Mental states are not identical to physical states because a mental state can be realized by multiple physical states (in different organisms).
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Mental states are computational states, not identified by their physical realizations but by their functional roles.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/functionalism/, Author: Janet Levin

records.line: The possibility of knowledge of any kind depends upon the possibility of an ‘absolute conception’ of the world.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: An objective ‘absolute conception’ of the world can be attained through natural science.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Knowledge is possible only if its possibility can be scientifically comprehended.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: There can be no external reasons for action; once they enter into our explanations of our actions, they become internal.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: A utilitarian assessment of duty is a form of alienation because the agent’s own welfare counts simply as someone’s welfare.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Marxism does not break radically enough with capitalism, offering itself merely as a more efficient and equitable organization of production.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/baudrillard/, Author: Douglas Kellner

records.line: Pre-capitalist societies were governed by laws of symbolic exchange rather than production and utility.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/baudrillard/, Author: Douglas Kellner

records.line: The catastrophe of modernity and eruption of postmodernity is produced by the unfolding of technological revolution.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/baudrillard/, Author: Douglas Kellner

records.line: Postmodern societies are organized around representations that ‘simulate’ reality as in television, cyberspace, and virtual reality.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/baudrillard/, Author: Douglas Kellner

records.line: Simulation is no longer a question of imitation, nor duplication, nor even parody; it is substituting the signs of the real for the real.
records.reference: Simulacra and Simulation,  Jean Baudrillard, U of Michigan P, 1994

records.line: Economics, politics, social life, and culture are all governed by the mode of simulation now.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/baudrillard/, Author: Douglas Kellner

records.line: Entertainment and information technologies provide experiences more intense and involving than the banal everyday life. (‘hyperreality’)
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/baudrillard/, Author: Douglas Kellner

records.line: As simulations proliferate, they come to refer only to themselves: a carnival of mirrors reflecting images projected from other mirrors.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/baudrillard/, Author: Douglas Kellner

records.line: The masses are now bathed in a ‘media massage’; classes disappear, and politics is dead, as are the dreams of disalienation, liberation, and revolution.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/baudrillard/, Author: Douglas Kellner

records.line: In postmodern societies, the masses seek spectacle and not meaning; they implode into a ‘silent majority.’
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/baudrillard/, Author: Douglas Kellner

records.line: Social theory is losing its very object as meanings, classes, and difference implode into a black hole of non-differentiation.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/baudrillard/, Author: Douglas Kellner

records.line: Free action does not require that an agent “could have done otherwise”.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: An agent is free when her ‘first-order’ intentions causing action are in harmony with her reflective ‘second-order’ intentions.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Writing is different from speech; the reader is absent when we write, and the author and his/her intentions are absent when we read.
records.reference: Derrida/Searle, Raoul Moati, Columbia University Press, 2014

records.line: The legibility of the text is indifferent to the communicational parameters (context, speaker, receiver, message) it first had.
records.reference: Derrida/Searle, Raoul Moati, Columbia University Press, 2014

records.line: The intended meaning of a text is incapable of being stabilized; rereading may activate new meanings (‘iteration’).
records.reference: Derrida/Searle, Raoul Moati, Columbia University Press, 2014

records.line: Every text is riddled with gaps, holes, and contradictions (‘aporias’).
records.reference: The Philosophy Book, DK Pub., 2011

records.line: Meaning is always deferred in language; it depends on what else we say, which depends on what else we say, and so on.
records.reference: The Philosophy Book, DK Pub., 2011

records.line: The meaning of the words we use depends on their relationship to (difference from) the words we are not using.
records.reference: The Philosophy Book, DK Pub., 2011

records.line: Meaning is not self-contained within the text, not even present to the author, because it is a matter of deferring and differing (‘différance’).
records.reference: The Philosophy Book, DK Pub., 2011

records.line: Explanation of a text has to grow indefinitely; there is nothing outside of the text.
records.reference: The Philosophy Book, DK Pub., 2011

records.line: We should expose the Platonistic dual hierarchies (good/evil, mind/body, etc.) in texts and mark them with new terms (‘deconstruction’).
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/derrida/, Author: Leonard Lawlor

records.line: There is no absolute distinction between the contributions of language and the world to the truth of what we say.
records.reference: Philosophy and the Mirror of Nature, Richard Rorty, Princeton University Press, 1979

records.line: Knowledge is a matter of conversation and of social practice, rather than as an attempt to mirror nature.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Philosophy is not any longer a constructive discipline; it is an edifying one concerned to expose illusion and to keep the conversation going.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: We should look forward to a post-Philosophical culture in which philosophy amounts to a study of the advantages of the various ways of talking.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Truth is what your contemporaries let you get away with.
records.reference: The Philosophy Book, DK Pub., 2011

records.line: Only one form of subjectivity exists in Western culture (religion, language, philosophy, psychoanalysis, etc.) and it is male.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/irigaray/, Author: Sarah K. Donovan

records.line: Women have historically been seen as “mother” (and “the other”) associated with nature, body, irrationality, and unthinking matter.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/irigaray/, Author: Sarah K. Donovan

records.line: Separating mind and body is unethical insofar as it perpetuates the division in culture between man/mind and woman/body.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/irigaray/, Author: Sarah K. Donovan

records.line: Science itself is biased towards categories typically personified as masculine (e.g. solids as opposed to fluids).
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/irigaray/, Author: Sarah K. Donovan

records.line: Language systems are malleable, and largely determined by power relationships that are in flux.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/irigaray/, Author: Sarah K. Donovan

records.line: Inclusion of women in the current form of subjectivity is not the solution; there should be more than one subject position in language.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/irigaray/, Author: Sarah K. Donovan

records.line: Both sexes have to reconfigure their subjectivity so that they both understand themselves as belonging equally to nature and culture.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/irigaray/, Author: Sarah K. Donovan

records.line: Five types of speech acts: assertives (e.g. statements), directives (e.g. orders), commissives (e.g. promises), expressives (e.g. thanks), and declarations (e.g. hirings).
records.reference: Encyclopædia Britannica, Article: John Searle, Contributor: Nicholas Fotion

records.line: There are indirect speech acts where the speaker performs one kind of speech act by means of performing another. (“You are standing on my foot.”)
records.reference: Encyclopædia Britannica, Article: John Searle, Contributor: Nicholas Fotion

records.line: Mental states are intrinsic and irreducible features of certain very complex kinds of biological system.
records.reference: Encyclopædia Britannica, Article: John Searle, Contributor: Nicholas Fotion

records.line: Unless a mental state has the potential to be conscious, it does not qualify as genuinely mental.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/intentionality/, Author: Pierre Jacob

records.line: Real understanding cannot be a matter of mere symbol manipulation; computers cannot be conscious.
records.reference: Encyclopædia Britannica, Article: John Searle, Contributor: Nicholas Fotion

records.line: Because mental states are biological, they can cause and be caused by physical changes in human bodies.
records.reference: Encyclopædia Britannica, Article: John Searle, Contributor: Nicholas Fotion

records.line: Language and other artifacts have intentionality derived from the ‘original/intrinsic intentionality’ of our conscious mental states.
records.reference: Mind, Language and Society, John Searle, Basic Books, 1999

records.line: Signification is illocutionary; linguistic conventions are sufficient to endow intentional meaning, independent of the presence of the sender.
records.reference: Derrida/Searle, Raoul Moati, Columbia University Press, 2014

records.line: We-intentions (collective intentions) are held by individuals but they are not reducible to I-intentions.
records.reference: Encyclopædia Britannica, Article: John Searle, Contributor: Nicholas Fotion

records.line: Objective social reality (games, money, language, etc.) is created by means of we-intentions.
records.reference: Encyclopædia Britannica, Article: John Searle, Contributor: Nicholas Fotion

records.line: Human beings have the capacity to be motivated by desire-independent reasons for action (such as promises).
records.reference: Freedom & Neurobiology, John Searle, Columbia University Press, 2007

records.line: It is possible to derive ‘ought’ from ‘is’ if we start from facts which concern human institutions (such as promises).
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Every event that falls under a special science predicate also falls under a physical predicate, but not vice versa.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/fodor/, Author: Bradley Rives

records.line: The special sciences are ‘autonomous’ with their irreducible generalizations about irreducible and casually efficacious higher-level properties.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/fodor/, Author: Bradley Rives

records.line: Brain states are like computer states, capable of representation in virtue of causal connections with the world.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Thought draws upon brain states which function as sentence-like representations.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: The mind contains a number of highly specialized, modular systems, whose operations are largely independent from each other.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/fodor/, Author: Bradley Rives

records.line: The brain’s central systems of belief fixation, planning, etc. are not modular; they are domain-general, unencapsulated.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/fodor/, Author: Bradley Rives

records.line: The complexity of our minds is irrelevant to the question of whether they’re the products of natural selection.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/fodor/, Author: Bradley Rives

records.line: The theory of natural selection cannot predict/explain what traits are selected-for and what traits are free-riders.
records.reference: What Darwin Got Wrong, Jerry Fodor & Massimo Piattelli-Palmarini, Profile Books, 2010

records.line: We cannot altogether abandon our subjectivity and fully objectify our knowledge (from a ‘view from nowhere’).
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Objective knowledge about an organism’s behaviour and physiology does not allow us to form a conception of its subjective experience.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Ethics is a branch of psychology.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: There are prudential, rational, timeless, internal reasons for action, independent of our current concerns.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Reasons for action are impersonal; if I act in some way on my own behalf, I should act the same way on behalf of others similarly situated.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: A detached (gender-free) position fails to do justice to facts that women are epistemically privileged with (such as sexual harassment).
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: A truly objective evaluation has to start by taking seriously the subjective standpoint of those who employ the judgements in question.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: For women, responsibilities arising from personal relationships are more important than abstract claims of justice.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: We should accept an ‘ethics of care’ which structure private life in addition to the more ‘masculine’ ethics of rights and duties.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: The strongest reason to advocate a libertarian society is that such advocacy follows from a respect for individual rights.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/nozick/, Author: Edward Feser

records.line: Individuals are self-owners; they have rights to their lives, liberty, and the fruits of their labor.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/nozick/, Author: Edward Feser

records.line: The endorsement of the imposition of sacrifices on individuals for social good fails to recognize the status of individuals as ends-in-themselves.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/nozick-political/, Author: Eric Mack

records.line: Just outcomes are those arrived at by the separate just actions of individuals; a particular distributive pattern is not required for justice.
records.reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, plato.stanford.edu/entries/justice-distributive/, Authors: Julian Lamont, Christi Favor

records.line: The various programs of the modern liberal welfare state (e.g. taxation) are immoral because they make slaves of the citizens of such a state.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/nozick/, Author: Edward Feser

records.line: The only sort of state that can be morally justified is a ‘minimal state’ which protects individuals from force via police and law, but does nothing else.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/nozick/, Author: Edward Feser

records.line: Knowledge is true belief that tracks the truth by varying according to the state of things in close possible worlds.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: There are rigid designators, names/descriptions that refer to the same thing in all possible worlds, which allow essentialist theses.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Ordinary proper names are rigid designators of ordinary things, thanks to fixations by ‘initial baptisms’.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: There are empirical necessary truths.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: There are contingent a priori truths.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: There are three types of essential necessity: origin, substance, and form.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: The essences of natural kinds can be illuminatingly identified in scientific terms.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Even if you have all the objective knowledge about color vision, seeing colors (‘qualia’) gives you new information.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Worlds that are merely possible are just as real as the actual world we happen to live in; these worlds are separate space-times.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Essentialist claims draw upon similarities between different, but similar, things (counterparts) in different worlds.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Our beliefs about what is possible/impossible concern the details of worlds that are altogether separate from our world.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Insofar as our mental states are causes of our physical actions, they too are physical, because physics is a ‘closed’ science.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Supervenience guarantees the reduction of the mental to the physical.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Mental-physical state identities should be restricted to species or even particular organisms.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: When you have all the objective knowledge about color vision, seeing a new color is not new factual knowledge but a new skill.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: There are cases where the requirement imposed by the situation and detected by the agent must exhaust his reason for acting as he does.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: ‘Properly brought up’ people are motivated to do what is required simply by recognizing an obligation, without deliberation.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: In moral conversions, a new awareness of external reasons for action creates a shift in motivation.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: The fact that the identity of moral values is dependent (like colors) upon a human point of view does not undermine their reality.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Moral values are best conceived as natural properties to be identified by inquiries in anthropology and sociology.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Moral values are explanatory properties. (e.g. Hitler’s wickedness is part of the explanation of the Holocaust.)
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: The explanatory role of moral values is to guide the identification of the natural properties which underpin this role.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: The utilitarian principle provides the basis for a naturalistic treatment of moral values.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: We should be able to justify our moral judgements with principles that others, similarly motivated, could not reject.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: It is reasons for action that are fundamental in the construction of justice.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Reasons for action are not dependent upon desires; finding such reasons motivates desires.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Reasons for action are sensitive to contextual considerations; they can sometimes be undermined.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: We start from our ordinary common-sense moral judgements and then refine them with our understanding of the world.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: There is a core of fundamental human rights, and there are judgements which exhibit a degree of cultural relativity.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: The objectivity of reasons for belief and action does not require uniformity of thought and practice; there can be different priorities.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: We are survival machines – robot vehicles blindly programmed to preserve the ‘selfish’ molecules (‘replicators’) known as genes.
records.reference: The Selfish Gene, Richard Dawkins, Oxford University Press, 1976

records.line: An animal’s behaviour tends to maximize the survival of the genes “for” that behaviour, whether or not those genes are in its body. (‘extended phenotype’)
records.reference: The Extended Phenotype, Richard Dawkins, Oxford University Press, 1982

records.line: Human culture evolves thanks to ‘memes’: information units replicating, mutating and being selected.
records.reference: The Selfish Gene, Richard Dawkins, Oxford University Press, 1976

records.line: A cultural trait may have evolved in the way that it has, simply because it is advantageous to itself.
records.reference: The Selfish Gene, Richard Dawkins, Oxford University Press, 1976

records.line: We, alone on earth, can rebel against the tyranny of the selfish replicators.
records.reference: The Selfish Gene, Richard Dawkins, Oxford University Press, 1976

records.line: The idea of evolution by natural selection unifies the realm of meaning and purpose with the realm of mechanism and physical law.
records.reference: Darwin’s Dangerous Idea, Daniel Dennett, Simon & Schuster, 1995

records.line: Reasons gradually emerged out of mere causes, ‘what for’s out of ‘how come’s, with no ‘essential’ dividing line between them.
records.reference: From Bacteria to Bach and Back, Daniel Dennett, Allen Lane, 2017

records.line: There were reasons tracked by evolution (‘free-floating rationales’) long before there were reason-representers like us.
records.reference: From Bacteria to Bach and Back, Daniel Dennett, Allen Lane, 2017

records.line: Comprehension is not the source of competence; it is composed of competences, and it comes in degrees.
records.reference: From Bacteria to Bach and Back, Daniel Dennett, Allen Lane, 2017

records.line: Our intentionality is gradually derived from the intentionality of our “selfish genes”, which is derived from the functional context of evolution.
records.reference: Intuition Pumps, Daniel Dennett, Penguin Books, 2013

records.line: With ‘the intentional stance’ we can treat something as an agent without committing to hypotheses about its internal structures.
records.reference: The Intentional Stance, Daniel Dennett, MIT Press, 1987

records.line: Meanings and thoughts do not show up within physics, but are apparent within ‘the intentional stance’ towards complex agents.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Minds are composed of simpler subsystems that are composed of teams of still simpler agents so stupid that they can be replaced by a machine.
records.reference: Brainstorms, Daniel Dennett, MIT Press, 1978

records.line: There is not a finish line or a center (a ‘Cartesian theater’) in the brain where the content is “presented” to the conscious subject.
records.reference: Consciousness Explained, Daniel Dennett, Little, Brown & Company, 1991

records.line: A self is like a center of (narrative) gravity: an abstract object, a theorist’s useful fiction – not a thing in the brain.
records.reference: Consciousness Explained, Daniel Dennett, Little, Brown & Company, 1991

records.line: All mental activity is accomplished in the brain by parallel, competitive processes of interpretation, under continuous editorial revision.
records.reference: Consciousness Explained, Daniel Dennett, Little, Brown & Company, 1991

records.line: Consciousness is a system of user-illusions evolved to make versions of our cognitive processes accessible to us for purposes of communication.
records.reference: From Bacteria to Bach and Back, Daniel Dennett, Allen Lane, 2017

records.line: We can study consciousness objectively by getting the subjects’ verbal accounts of their conscious experiences (‘heterophenomenology’).
records.reference: Consciousness Explained, Daniel Dennett, Little, Brown & Company, 1991

records.line: Free will (like colors, dollars, promises) is part of the user-illusion of the manifest image that we shouldn’t want to dismantle; it’s where we live.
records.reference: From Bacteria to Bach and Back, Daniel Dennett, Allen Lane, 2017

records.line: Qualia are in fact the intentional objects of mistaken beliefs that simply don’t exist, anywhere.
records.reference: From Bacteria to Bach and Back, Daniel Dennett, Allen Lane, 2017

records.line: There might be variations of consciousness from poet to possum to protozoon, and no ‘essence’ of consciousness to discover.
records.reference: From Bacteria to Bach and Back, Daniel Dennett, Allen Lane, 2017

records.line: Memes turned our brains into minds capable of dealing with ideas, thanks to the apps installed in our ‘necktops’.
records.reference: From Bacteria to Bach and Back, Daniel Dennett, Allen Lane, 2017

records.line: Brains are computers, but they are very unlike the computers in use today.
records.reference: From Bacteria to Bach and Back, Daniel Dennett, Allen Lane, 2017

records.line: Unlike our computers and flip-flops, organisms and neurons are competitive agents; this may be their key difference.
records.reference: From Bacteria to Bach and Back, Daniel Dennett, Allen Lane, 2017
