records.line: Brains are more like termite colonies than intelligently designed corporations or armies.
records.reference: From Bacteria to Bach and Back, Daniel Dennett, Allen Lane, 2017

records.line: In our moral judgements we express our feelings (which are a species of desire), not describe them.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Our talk of ethics is quasi-realist; our feelings color our experience of the world by projecting values onto it.
records.reference: Contemporary Philosophy, Thomas Baldwin, Oxford University Press, 2001

records.line: Gender is produced through ways in which language, bodily gestures, movements, and styles constitute the illusion of an abiding gendered self.
records.reference: Gender Trouble, Judith Butler, Routledge, 1990

records.line: “I” only exists within signifying practices; gender acts are not performed by the subject, they performatively constitute the subject.
records.reference: Gender Trouble, Judith Butler, Routledge, 1990

records.line: Gender has no essence, no ontological status apart from the various repetitive acts which constitute its reality.
records.reference: Gender Trouble, Judith Butler, Routledge, 1990

records.line: The very notion of an essential, “natural” sex is constituted as part of the strategy that conceals gender’s performative character.
records.reference: Gender Trouble, Judith Butler, Routledge, 1990

records.line: It is impossible to separate gender from the political and cultural intersections (racial, class, ethnic, sexual, regional) in which it is produced.
records.reference: Gender Trouble, Judith Butler, Routledge, 1990

records.line: The tasks of explaining the performance of the cognitive functions (perception, attention, memory, etc.) are easy problems.
records.reference: "Facing up to the problem of consciousness," David Chalmers, Journal of Consciousness Studies V2 N3, 1995

records.line: The task of explaining why the performance of cognitive functions are accompanied by experience is the unique, hard problem of consciousness.
records.reference: "Facing up to the problem of consciousness," David Chalmers, Journal of Consciousness Studies V2 N3, 1995

records.line: Even when we have solved all the easy problems of cognitive function, the hard problem of consciousness may still remain unsolved.
records.reference: "Facing up to the problem of consciousness," David Chalmers, Journal of Consciousness Studies V2 N3, 1995

records.line: The reason that reductive explanation fails for consciousness is that it cannot be functionally analyzed.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/hard-con/, Author: Josh Weisberg

records.line: ‘Zombies’ (creatures physically and functionally identical to us, but lacking consciousness) are conceivable.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/hard-con/, Author: Josh Weisberg

records.line: A natural kind term has a primary intension (its sense, description) and a secondary intension (its reference in this world, and thus in every world).
records.reference: The Conscious Mind, David Chalmers, Oxford UP, 1996

records.line: Two-dimensional semantics bridge the epistemic and modal domains, in arguing from conceivability to metaphysical possibility.
records.reference: The Character of Consciousness, David Chalmers, Oxford UP, 2010

records.line: The conceivability of ‘zombies’ (and of spectrum inversion, of the “knowledge argument”, etc.) proves that consciousness cannot be functionally analyzed.
records.reference: The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, iep.utm.edu/hard-con/, Author: Josh Weisberg

records.line: We may have to take experience itself as a fundamental feature of the world, alongside mass, charge, and space-time.
records.reference: "Facing up to the problem of consciousness," David Chalmers, Journal of Consciousness Studies V2 N3, 1995

records.line: Fundamental entities bearing micro(proto)phenomenal properties may be constituting the macrophenomenal realm.
records.reference: “Panpsychism and Panprotopsychism,” David Chalmers, The Amherst Lecture in Philosophy 8, 2013

records.line: “Information” may be fundamental for experience, with its two aspects corresponding to the physical and to the phenomenal features of the world.
records.reference: "Facing up to the problem of consciousness," David Chalmers, Journal of Consciousness Studies V2 N3, 1995

records.line: Even a thermostat might have maximally simple phenomenal experience as a maximally simple information-processing structure.
records.reference: "Facing up to the problem of consciousness," David Chalmers, Journal of Consciousness Studies V2 N3, 1995
